Ça me gave.

Là, l'oie, c'est moi !
Choose a level.

objects.name: Controls
objects.string:
arrows and RShift - ESDF and LShift - IJKL and H - 8456 and 0
or gamepads

events.comment: Settings chosen in the scene "Selection" are applied.
The player variables can't be used in an expression if no condition nor action referred to it. The repeat loop takes that role.

Check that no bomb is already on this square.
The negation of "Is there at least one bomb on this square?" is equivalent to "Is there no bomb on this square?".
This is not the same as having the negation directly on the condition because it would mean "Is there a bomb that is not on this square?".

The variable IsNew allows to apply some actions on the created bombes without the player in the context.
Otherwise, the loop on the players wouldn't work because GDevelop couldn't tell on which player to apply actions.
Other players can be on the square where the bomb is put.
The player no longer overlaps the bomb. It becomes solid for this player.
A bomb can explode because of the detonator...
...or by chain reaction
Every death counts.
Dead player come back to their initial location.
Random bonus creation
The crate is removed after because its location is used to create the bonus.
Give the player its bomb back.
Called in "Game" and "Death".

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Gustavo Marciano
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: YSort
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Create an illusion of depth by setting the Z-order based on the Y position of the object. Useful for isometric games, 2D games with a "Top-Down" view, RPG...
description: Set the depth (Z-order) of the instance to the value of its Y position in the scene, creating an illusion of depth. The origin point of the object is used to determine the Z-order.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Set the depth (Z-order) of the instance to the value of its Y position in the scene, creating an illusion of depth. The origin point of the object is used to determine the Z-order.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: YSort

events.comment: This is done in doStepPostEvents because the sort must happens right before the rendering to avoid a 1 frame delay.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: BehaviorRemapper
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Quickly remap Behavior controls to different keys.
description: Make sure to disable default controls unless you want two keys to do the same action.
Actions have two versions. `custom` allow the movement keys to be changed to what ever you would like. `presets` provide a common key-bindings that can be selected from a list.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Allows for the controls of a Top-Down behavior to be re-mapped via a single action.

/** Analyze the real intent of the player instead of applying the input blindly.
* @returns {integer} a direction that matches the player intents.
// Compute the list of the objects that will be used
// Used to align the player when the assistance make him bypass an obstacle
// Incites of how the player should be assisted
// This affectation has no meaning, it will be override.
// Extends the box in the player direction
// The player is corner to corner to the obstacle.
// The assistance will depend on other obstacles.
// Both direction are set and the actual to take
// The player is not on the corner of the obstacle.
// Set the assistance both ways to fall back in
// the same case as 2 obstacles side by side
// The player is on the corner of the obstacle.
// (not the exact corner, see corner affectation)
// In case the cornerSize is bigger than the obstacle size,
// go the on the shortest side.
// The player is not on the corner of the obstacle.
// Set the assistance both ways to fall back in
// the same case as 2 obstacles side by side
// The player is on the corner of the obstacle.
// (not the exact corner, see corner affectation)
// This may happen when the player is in the corner of 2 perpendicular walls.
// This may happen when the player goes in diagonal against a wall.
// Make him follow the wall. This allows player to keep full speed.
// When he collided a square from the wall corner to corner,
// a 3rd assistance may be true but it fall back in the same case.
// This can happen, for instance, with a wall composed of squares.
// Taken separately from one to another, a square could be bypass one the right
// and the next one on the left even though they are side by side
// and the player can't actually go between them.
// The player goes in diagonal and is corner to corner with the obstacle.
// (but not against a wall, this time)
// The velocity is used to decide.
// This may only happen after an alignment.
// Slide on the corner of an obstacle to bypass it.
// Every tricky cases are already handled .
// Check if there is any obstacle in the way.
// There must be no obstacle to go at least
// as far in the direction the player chose
// as the assistance must take to align the player.
// Because, if the assistance moves the player by 32 pixels
// before been able to go in the right direction
// and can only move by 4 pixels afterward
// Don't check again if the player intent stays the same.
// Do it, for instance, if an obstacle has moved out of the way
// and the player releases and presses agin the key.
// Because, doing it automatically would seems weird.
// Because the obstacle may not be a square.
// min and max are preserved by the symmetry.
// The symmetry image is extended to check there is no obstacle before going into the passage.
// Because the obstacle may not be a square.
// min and max are switched by the symmetry.
// The symmetry image is extended to check there is no obstacle before going into the passage.
// check again because the object can be pushed on the stop limit,
// it won't be detected on the next frame and the alignment won't be applied.
* Check if the object must take a corner.
* When the object reach the limit of an obstacle
* and it should take the corner according to the player intent,
* it is aligned right on this limit and the velocity is set in the right direction.
* This avoid issues with the inertia. For instance,
* when the object could go between 2 obstacles,
* with it will just fly over the hole because of its inertia.
// Alignment: avoid to go too far and kind of drift or oscillate in front of a hole.
// Search the obstacle with the biggest intersection
// to separate from this one first.
// Because smaller collisions may shift the player
* Separate object and obstacle, only object move.
for (let h = 0, lenh = hitBoxes.length; h < lenh; ++h) {
for (let p = 0, lenp = hitBox.vertices.length; p < lenp; ++p) {

events.comment: Initiate and attach properties as objects variables

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Bouh
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Gamepads
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Add support for gamepads (or other controllers) to your game, giving access to information such as button presses, axis positions, trigger pressure, etc...
description: Add support for gamepads (or other controllers) to your game, giving access to information such as button presses, axis positions, axis force, trigger pressure, deadzone for each gamepad, etc...
Up to 4 gamepads can be connected. For each condition or expression, you'll have to enter the index of the gamepad to read. This is 1, 2, 3 or 4.

eventsFunctions.description: Get the value of the pressure on a gamepad trigger.
eventsFunctions.name: TriggerPressure

inlineCode: console.error('Parameter gamepad identifier in expression: "Pressure on a gamepad trigger", is not valid number, must be between 0 and 4.');

//we need keep this condition because when use have not yet plug her controller we can't get the controller in the gamepad variable.

Get the force value of a gamepad stick.
0 is stick on default position, 1 is at the maximum.

eventsFunctions.description:
Get the rotation value of a gamepad stick.
If the deadzone value is high, the angle value is rounded to main axes, left, left, up, down.
An zero deadzone value give a total freedom on the angle value.

eventsFunctions.description: Set the deadzone for sticks of the gamepad. The deadzone is an area for which movement on sticks won't be taken into account (instead, the stick will be considered as not moved). Deadzone is between 0 and 1, and is by default 0.2.

events.comment: The arm squares (+11) are over the finger squares (+10) and the center squares are over the other 2 (+12). It makes a better continuity on the explosions sprites.
When an obstacle is reached, the loop is broken (by setting a big value in the iteration variable).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Play the explosion animation and destroy itself.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ExplosionAnimator

events.comment: The animation frame rate can only be constant. So, the animation is split to make the last frame last.
